meta.title: Trailer - HTTP | MDN
meta.desc:
The Trailer response header allows the sender to include additional
  fields at the end of chunked messages in order to supply metadata that might be
  dynamically generated while the message body is sent, such as a message integrity check,
  digital signature, or post-processing status.

> When a browser downloads an image file, it can start rendering it right away, before itâ€™s even finished downloading the whole thing.
> With a JavaScript file, the browser waits for the whole thing to download, then it compiles it,Â *then*Â it reads through the whole file top-to-bottom to see whatâ€™s in it. If there are ES imports,Â *those*Â need to get downloaded, compiled, and read, too.
> While all of that stuff I just described is happening, the browser stops rendering the UI until itâ€™s finished. Because JavaScript often modifies the DOM, browsers stop rendering anything until they know what the JS file is going to do.
> This helps them avoid painting things that are just going to be removed by JavaScript anyways.

meta.title: Modern SPAs without bundlers, CDNs, or NodeJS
meta.desc: I typically start new front-end prototypes with a single HTML file that I view using a file:// URL. I enjoy this practice of incrementally growing my projects, so Iâ€™ll keep working in that single file for as long as I can. Once it becomes unwieldy, Iâ€™ll split out the CSS and JavaScript into dedicated files. Then when manual DOM manipulation gets too complex, Iâ€™ll reach for a front-end framework. Until recently though, I wasnâ€™t sure how to make this step feel incremental. Most framework installations recommend npm install, which means my project will now depend on NodeJS. Some frameworks have a hosted CDN option, but Iâ€™m similarly uncomfortable accepting that infrastructural dependency. Ideally, Iâ€™d just grab the framework files, import them from my JavaScript, and then carry on with my file:// URL.

meta.title: React is still absolutely terrible for web performance
meta.desc:
One of the oft-repeated myths I hear from framework evangelists is that tools like React are better for performance because â€œthey use a virtual DOM instead of the real DOM.â€
First, thatâ€™s objectively false.
In certain situations (like UIs with comically large amounts of div nesting) moving DOM diffing to a virtual layer can improve the performance of that specific step. But eventually, they have to touch the real DOM. Thatâ€™s how you manipulate and update elements.
